newsitem.title: MONTSERRAT: Montserrat volcano forces radio station shutdown.
newsitem.headline: Montserrat volcano forces radio station shutdown.

text.p: Montserrat's Radio Antilles, which survived a hurricane eight years ago, will close at the end of May due to problems caused by the island's active volcano, the Caribbean News Agency reported on Friday.
The Barbados-based agency, quoting a radio station official, said the board announced the decision to close to management and staff after a meeting on Wednesday.
The official attributed the closing to financial problems and the difficulty of operating since the volcano forced the station to relocate.

Staff at the station, which had relayed the Voice of America and the BBC to much of the Caribbean, had managed to keep it operating in the months since the British island colony's Soufriere Hills volcano roared to life in July 1995.

The station was forced to relocate from its base in the southern part of the island, considered most threatened by the active volcano, but was able to stay on the air and keep eight staff members working.
Scientists last weekend raised the island's volcano alert level after its activity increased. It remained at the "Orange" level on Friday.
